articles.headline: Shops on Wheels, but the Goods Aren’t Sold From the Trunk
articles.snippet: Mobile businesses are increasing in cities across the United States, as entrepreneurs embrace the lower overhead and freedom to change locations.
articles.abstract: Mobile businesses are increasing in cities across the United States, as entrepreneurs embrace the lower overhead and freedom to change locations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most weekday mornings, Jessie Goldenberg can be found driving around the Flatiron district or Lower Manhattan searching for just the right parking space for her truck. And Black Friday will be no different, as competition for consumer dollars heats up for the holiday season.

articles.headline: Now, Anyone Can Buy a Drone. Heaven Help Us.
articles.snippet: Pranksters’ antics are forcing public safety officials to look at the air above them, generally thought safe and secure, as a place for potential trouble.
articles.abstract: Pranksters’ antics are forcing public safety officials to look at the air above them, generally thought safe and secure, as a place for potential trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amateur photographers and Hollywood filmmakers turn to them for lush overhead shots. Geologists use them to look above the seas for oil-bearing rocks. Amazon executives are pushing to use them to plop packages onto doorsteps.

articles.headline: U.S. Adds Planes to Bolster Drive to Wipe Out ISIS
articles.snippet: The United States is shifting aircraft from Afghanistan to the Middle East, but the Islamic State, a hybrid between a conventional army and a terrorist network, has been difficult to target.
articles.abstract: The United States is shifting aircraft from Afghanistan to the Middle East, but the Islamic State, a hybrid between a conventional army and a terrorist network, has been difficult to target.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHAW AIR FORCE BASE, S.C. — The United States is shifting more attack and surveillance aircraft from Afghanistan to the air war against the Islamic State, deepening American involvement in the conflict and presenting new challenges for the military planners who work here in central South Carolina, far from the targets they will pick for those aircraft.

articles.headline: Obama Builds Environmental Legacy With 1970 Law
articles.snippet: Leaning on the Clean Air Act, President Obama has reshaped environmental policy more than any previous occupant of the White House.
articles.abstract: Leaning on the Clean Air Act, President Obama has reshaped environmental policy more than any previous occupant of the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama could leave office with the most aggressive, far-reaching environmental legacy of any occupant of the White House. Yet it is very possible that not a single major environmental law will have passed during his two terms in Washington.

articles.headline: In France, New Review of 35-Hour Workweek
articles.snippet: The Socialist government is rethinking a law that was meant to create jobs but lately has been criticized for adding to the country’s economic woes.
articles.abstract: The Socialist government is rethinking a law that was meant to create jobs but lately has been criticized for adding to the country’s economic woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent weekday, Ahlem Saifi caught a 5 a.m. Métro to get to her job as a passengers’ assistant at Orly Airport, where she often works 44 hours a week — well over France’s official 35-hour workweek.

articles.headline: Simple, Even Retro, Toys Gain Favor This Christmas
articles.snippet: Arts and crafts, robotic animals, retro toys and toys based on popular children’s movies are in high demand this year, as parents look for alternatives to digital diversions.
articles.abstract: Arts and crafts, robotic animals, retro toys and toys based on popular children’s movies are in high demand this year, as parents look for alternatives to digital diversions.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a moment in Seth MacFarlane’s comedy “A Million Ways to Die in the West,” set in the 1880s, where a boy rolls a hoop down the street with a stick.

articles.headline: Legal Fight Pits Sellers of Energy Against Buyers
articles.snippet: A system under which big consumers shut down elevator banks or a production line at peak hours of electricity demand has been challenged by power producers, who lose their most valuable revenue hours.
articles.abstract: A system under which big consumers shut down elevator banks or a production line at peak hours of electricity demand has been challenged by power producers, who lose their most valuable revenue hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, the federal government has nurtured the growth of an odd kind of player in the energy markets: companies that recruit consumers to unplug themselves when electricity use is high, in exchange for a price break.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Experts Weigh Officer’s Decisions Leading to Fatal Shooting of Michael Brown
articles.snippet: Many experts said that Darren Wilson acted within the bounds of protocol, though some said the quick escalation of the fatal encounter could have been avoided.
articles.abstract: Many experts said that Darren Wilson acted within the bounds of protocol, though some said the quick escalation of the fatal encounter could have been avoided.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his first public interview this week, Darren Wilson, the white police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., was asked whether he could have done anything differently that would have prevented the killing.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: After Disputed Verdict, Reckoning for Ferguson
articles.snippet: In a way, the questions about the future of a few heavily damaged blocks of West Florissant Avenue in Ferguson are larger than the individual stores that lined it.
articles.abstract: In a way, the questions about the future of a few heavily damaged blocks of West Florissant Avenue in Ferguson are larger than the individual stores that lined it.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — It was never much, a faded commercial strip on a stretch that drew people from the apartments nearby for most of the essentials. You could pick up milk at the convenience store, get a manicure at Crystal Nails, wash your clothes at the Ferguson Laundry. On a busy Friday night, men would gather to talk and watch sports on television at the barber shop as they got straight razor shaves.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: On Holiday, Ferguson Seeks to Salve Wounds
articles.snippet: Residents painted art on boarded-up shops, a pastor of a destroyed church visited another worship space and the National Guard stood at the ready to secure the streets in the area.
articles.abstract: Residents painted art on boarded-up shops, a pastor of a destroyed church visited another worship space and the National Guard stood at the ready to secure the streets in the area.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The people who came to this boarded-up downtown on Thursday morning knew they could not do much to salve Ferguson’s wounds. But it was Thanksgiving, and they felt they could not just sit home, either. So they brought paint brushes and prayers, thermoses of coffee and trays of drop biscuits, hoping to counterbalance the arsons, angry protests and racial strife.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: OPEC Holds Production Unchanged; Prices Fall
articles.snippet: The 30 percent decline in oil prices in recent months has shaken the solidarity of the 12-member Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.
articles.abstract: The 30 percent decline in oil prices in recent months has shaken the solidarity of the 12-member Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The oil cartel OPEC decided on Thursday not to cut petroleum production, despite the plunge in prices in recent months that has indicated the diminishing clout of the organization.
